awd_titl_txt: Pollutant formation during oxy-combustion of coal
awd_abstract_narration:
Carbon dioxide emissions from combustion of fossil fuels is of great concern for global warming. A technology being considered for carbon capture and sequestration in power plants is oxy-coal combustion. Thus, the operational and environmental impacts of oxy-coal combustion need to be evaluated. Sulfur dioxide emissions can also be reduced with oxy-firing compared to air combustion due to high concentrations of sulfur trioxide in the flue gas resulting in sulfur retention on fly ash and ash deposits in the furnace. Higher sulfur retention on the ash particles reduces the sulfur dioxide emission rates, on the other hand it creates problems utilizing the fly ash for cement and concrete production. Further research regarding the sulfur dioxide emissions under oxy-firing conditions needs to be performed, specifically to investigate the fly ash retention. In comparison to the emissions of nitrogen and sulfur oxides, the subject of trace metal emissions in oxy-fuel combustion has not received much attention in the literature and little information has been reported on the mercury transformations under oxy-fired conditions. One area of concern is that the pollutants such as mercury and sulfur trioxide cause corrosion in carbon dioxide compressors and recirculation lines. The characteristics of oxy-combustion and air-combustion are fairly different and this results in changes in the behavior of pollutants in the flue gas, thus the emissions. As research in this area is beginning to grow, the fundamental understanding of pollutant formation remains to be elucidated and before developing removal technologies, one needs to understand the speciation and behavior of these pollutants under oxy-fired conditions. The objective of this project is to investigate the differences in pollutant behavior under air- and oxy-fired conditions. This research is unique in the fact that it will be the first comprehensive investigation of pollutant formation during oxy-fuel combustion at a fundamental level combining bench-scale experiments, kinetic modeling and molecular modeling. Two major milestones that will be achieved by the end of this project are the following: 1) Gas phase chemistry of sulfur oxides and trace metals will be elucidated by both bench-scale experiments and kinetic modeling and effects of other flue gas constituents and the recycling will be determined 2) Heterogeneous chemistry of sulfur oxides and trace metals on fly ash will be investigated by bench-scale experiments and molecular modeling and the mechanism of sulfur retention on fly ash will be identified.

This research will provide useful information for the oxy-fired power plants regarding the risk of corrosion associated with the pollutants in the flue gas as well as the extent of sulfur retention on fly ash that could prevent them selling the fly ash to concrete producers. Besides the practical knowledge, it will also provide a fundamental understanding of the pollutant chemistry that is taking place in the flue gas and on the fly ash surface. Experimental data that will be produced from this project will be made available in the literature and could be used to validate the existing models in the literature. Additionally, the graduate and undergraduate students working on this project will gain an in-depth knowledge of combustion chemistry as well as excellent experimental and modeling skills.

por.por_cntn:
The Intellectual Merit: This work is the first comprehensive investigation of pollutant formation during oxy-coal combustion at a fundamental level combining bench-scale experiments and molecular modeling. During the course of this project two bench-scale experimental systems have been designed and built to study oxy-combustion including a gas phase reactor and a packed-bed reactor to study heterogeneous interactions. Experiments have been conducted in conjunction with the modeling work to study sulfur chemistry in simulated oxy-combustion flue gas as well as on the fly ash surface to investigate sulfur retention on fly ash. For the gas phase chemistry, the speciation data collected from the experiments to obtain temporal profiles of sulfur oxides (SO2 and SO3) is the first of its kind. Through kinetic simulations, dominant reaction pathways for the formation of pollutants, e.g. SO3, have been determined. In addition, the interaction between nitrogen oxide and sulfur oxides has been studied for the first time and direct interactions between these pollutants have been shown to occur. For the heterogeneous chemistry, the interactions of sulfur oxides with the fly ash components (CaO, MgO, Na2O and K2O) have been investigated by molecular modeling employing density functional theory as well as simulated flue gas experiments to better understand the mechanism of sulfur retention on fly ash.

The Broader Impacts: This research will provide useful information for the oxy-fired power plants regarding the risk of corrosion associated with the pollutants in the flue gas as well as the extent of sulfur retention on fly ash that could prevent them selling the fly ash to concrete producers. Besides the practical knowledge, the proposed work also provides a fundamental understanding of the pollutant chemistry that is taking place in the flue gas and on the fly ash surface. Experimental data that is produced from this project will be made available in the literature and could be used to validate the existing models in the literature.

Dissemination: One peer-reviewed journal article has been published in the journal Fuel [1] as well as a conference paper [2]. Two other manuscripts have been submitted to the Fuel [3] and Applied Energy [4] journals, while another manuscript is in preparation. The results of this work have been disseminated via 11 conference presentations (7 oral, 4 poster) given by the graduate students, 2 invited seminars and 1 invited talk at the USC Energy Leadership Institute Forum given by the PI. The PI is also invited to give a talk at the International Symposium on Chemical Reactions Engineering conference in June 2016.

 

1.         Galloway, B.D., E. Sasmaz, and B. Padak, Binding of SO3 to fly ash components: CaO, MgO, Na2O and K2O. Fuel, 2015. 145: p. 79-83.

2.         Choudhury, N. and B. Padak. SO3 Formation during Oxy-coal Combustion. in 40th International Conference on Clean Coal &Fuel Systems. 2015. Clearwater, FL.

3.         Galloway, B.D., R. MacDonald, and B. Padak, Characterization of Sulfur Products on CaO at High Temperatures for Air and Oxy-combustion. submitted to Fuel (under review), 2015.

4.         Choudhury, N. and B. Padak, A Comprehensive Experimental and Modeling Study of SO3 Formation in Oxy-fuel Combustion. submitted to Applied Energy, 2015.
